Some kind of a "perfect family game" or "filler" allowing various players, from kids to core, to share a nice moment together and to tease each others in the same time.

You said "Roll, HIDE & Write" ?

On each turn, the active player rolls 3 dice but only shows 2 to other players: all the player now have to fill their individual house of cats with these two results. Then, the active player reveals the hidden die! Whether this surprise is good or bad, all players have to place it in their house, respecting a strict condition. Yes, simple! But also very cheeky... and an intense source of interaction between players.

—description from the publisher

Name: Uncontained: An SCP Card Game
Description:
Set in the extensive stories of the SCP Foundation, Uncontained is a strategic card game featuring all-time favorites like SCP-173, SCP-682, and SCP-096! In this card game, prepare to contain anomalous SCP items, sacrifice D-Class Personnel, play scientists and insurgents, and survive cataclysmic scenarios in order to win the game.

Inspired by Unstable Unicorns and the Call of Cthulhu LCG, the overall gameplay of Uncontained is quite generic: you draw cards from the Draw pile, and do things with those cards. However, there's a twist: most cards don't really go to your hand and are immediately played on the board for everyone to see. Some cards would still go to your hand, and if they do, they should be able to give you an edge. There's also a dedicated Public pile that contains the Civilian cards which act as the game's general resource.

Your goal Uncontained is to Contain as many Anomaly cards as possible. When an anomaly is drawn, it's by default Uncontained (placed in a special area called the Uncontained zone), and must be Contained during your turn through "Sacrificing" civilian cards. Each anomaly is unique and can either harm or benefit you, depending on its contained or uncontained status.

The player with the most Contained anomaly cards when the draw pile runs out wins the game! Or the last player standing, in case everyone gets knocked out by SCP-370!

The SCP Foundation Wiki and this game are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License.

Get the game here: https://www.thegamecrafter.com/games/uncontained
Print and Play download: https://kenoma.itch.io/scp-card-game

Name: Pet Royale
Description:
A fast-paced pet themed resource management game, Pet Royale was created to:

Be easily explained and playable within minutes;
 Promote a healthy level of interaction and thinking (outwit, out-do, outmanoeuvre);

Players take turns to place their cards in the map filled with resources, and the pets (cards) battle it out in individual duels to obtain the resource.

The first person to collect six resource tokens or win three battles wins!

—description from the publisher

Name: Hertzschlag
Description:
Hertzschlag is a semi-cooperative game about the power grid, renewable energies and a looming blackout.

Players represent communities of households whose decisions impact the power frequency. Getting a solar panel on your roof increases the overall amount of electricity produced and thus increases the frequency. Getting an electric car in contrast consumes more electricity, hence lowering the frequency.

Furthermore, events like unexpected and extreme weather influences how much wind and solar energy is produced and can unbalance the frequency which players need to rebalance through their choices.

Players have secret goals that award victory points at the end of the game and try to win by having most. However, if the frequency is too unbalanced and players fail at rebalancing it, a blackout happens and all players lose immediately. Concluding, players need to cooperate at least a bit to prevent a blackout. Or should you focus on your own personal goals and hope that other players will prevent a blackout?!

—description from the publisher

Name: Unfold Kids: Kid's Quest – Mission Cookies
Description:
You are not an ordinary child because you have superpowers, and your parents are secret agents. You have longed for them to take you on a real assignment. To prove that you are old enough for an undercover mission, you are going to find the most secret room in your superhero house. And Elp — your Electronic home assistant — is always ready to help you out with a hint or put you on the right track.

Kid’s Quest. Mission ‘Cookies’ is an exciting tabletop quest designed specifically for children. Open new locations, solve unique puzzles and complete your mission, relying not only on your smarts but on your senses as well. Learn more about the character's family and watch the story unfold as you play.

This is a tabletop quest in the form of two fold-out envelopes. The players are not allowed to unfold them immediately. Read the story page by page until you come across a puzzle. Use logic, good reasoning and sometimes your senses to solve each puzzle. If you are stuck, you can always look up a hint or solution with a short explanation of the puzzle. Do not open new pages unless you are instructed to do so. Usually, you'll need to solve a puzzle in order to turn over a page. As soon as you reach the page stating "To be continued..." or "The End", you have successfully finished the game!

—description from the publisher

Name: Not Alone: Sanctuary – The Promo Cards
Description: Pack including the stretch goal cards from the Not Alone: Sanctuary kickstarter. Features 4x The Mists location, 4x The Drone location, 2 Hunt cards, 2 Survival cards, 2 Survivor cards, 3 Evolution cards, 3 Avatar cards and 1 rules clarification card.

Name: Tomtens julspel
Description:
What does the word Advent mean?
What is the plot called in Norway?
When did Arne Weise end up as Christmas host?

What do you know about Christmas baking, Christmas trees, Christmas calendars, Christmas in other countries, Christmas food, Jesus, Santa, Lucia and much more?

Question cards, Christmas songs and Christmas rhymes for adults and children.

The game is about collecting Merry Christmas tokens. Most tokens at the end of the game win. The correct answer gives a token unless the card indicates otherwise.

There are five types of cards; Question cards, True or False cards, Christmas rhymes, Humming cards and theme cards.

—user summary

Name: Warhammer 40,000 (Eighth Edition): Imperium Nihilus – Vigilus Defiant
Description:
War ravages the sentinel world of Vigilus. Though beset by an Ork Speedwaagh! and a Genestealer Cult uprising, its crucial location at the mouth of the Nachmund Gauntlet makes it an invaluable asset to the Imperium – one that its people will fight to the last to defend. Yet this defiance may cost the Imperium dearly, for on top of all the planet’s woes, a Chaos invasion has begun, led by a warlord claiming to be the herald of Abaddon himself!

Imperium Nihilus: Vigilus Defiant is packed with exciting background and new rules that enable you to refight the events described in the book. Here’s what you will find inside:

- Background of the period leading up to the War for Vigilus 
- A star map of the Vigilus system
- Descriptions of the planet of Vigilus and its military disposition
- Detailed accounts of the major events in the War for Vigilus
- Campaign deployment maps and descriptions of the battles that were fought in each war zone
- Details of the various armies that fought in this campaign
- Campaign rules allowing you to bring the narrative of this book to life on your tabletop.
- Guidance on organising and running a Vigilus campaign
-12 narrative play missions (6 Crucible of War, 6 Echoes of War), as well as additional special rules and stratagems 
- Six exciting battlezones to use in your games of Warhammer 40,000
- Specific rules for using the various factions that fought on Vigilus, including datasheets for Marneus Calgar, his Victrix Guard and Haarken Worldclaimer
- 22 specialist detachments, with new warlord traits, relics, and stratagems

Name: Table Battles: The Grand Alliance
Description:
The fifth expansion to Tom Russell's popular Table Battles series recreates six battles - two from the Nine Years War and four from the War of the Spanish Succession - the age of Eugene and Marlborough, Villars and Luxembourg. Unique to this set is the introduction of a "link" - a relationship between two formations that mitigates casualties. Some scenarios also allow players to shift unit sticks from one part of the battlefield to another. The six battles are Fleurus, Marsaglia, Chiari, Blenheim, Ramillies, and Denain.

—description from the publisher
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: Our God Was My Shield: Jackson's Valley Campaign
Description:
Our God Was My Shield is the first game in John Theissen's American Civil War Operational Series (ACWOS). This series of streamlined card-assisted operational sandboxes builds on Mr. Theissen's work in titles such as More Aggressive Attitudes, Objective Shreveport, and Hood's Last Gamble. Those games had slightly different and not entirely compatible rulesets - each one needed to be learned from scratch. But titles in the new ACWOS share a common core ruleset: learn one game, and you'll know how to play the rest of them. This ruleset is flexible enough to allow each game to have its own geographic and temporal scale and Combat Results Table, as well as special event cards unique to that campaign.

Specific units and their strengths are hidden from your opponent as you perform a tense dance of cat-and-mouse maneuvers. When you attack your opponent, there's always a chance they might slip away - or, they might be able to concentrate additional forces, turning what you thought would be an easy victory into a near-run thing, especially if your own forces fail to coordinate. Knowing when to attack and when to hold back, when to run and when to make a stand, are paramount, and as ever, subject to the fortunes of war.

The subject of our first title in this series is Jackson's famous 1862 Valley Campaign, which saw him eluding and harassing three Union armies through a combination of boldness and deception. It is perhaps an ideal subject with which to debut this system with its emphasis on maneuver, bluff, and nerve.

—description from the publisher
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Lairs, Dens and Burrows: Short adventures for Four Against Darkness, for Characters of Any Level
Description:
Sometimes, you do not have the time to play a full dungeon, or maybe you just want something different between two long missions.
Lairs, Dens and Burrows is a collection of short encounters for the Four Against Darkness solo rules that are just perfect for that.
The nine super-short adventures presented here, for parties of any experience level, include:

     On Our Way Home 
     The Lair of the Gray Orcs
     Nest of the Manticore
     An OId Man Gave Me This Map
     The Nixie in the Wine-Skin
     The Ivy-Covered Hole
     The Hyena Pack
     The Mayhem Machine
     The Dark Unicorn.

Name: Victory at Sea: Kongo
Description:
KongÅ (é‡‘å‰›, “Indestructible Diamond”), named for the mountain, was the first battleship of her class, serving in both the first and second world wars. At the time of construction in the early 1910s she was a capital ship (the last Japanese Capital ship to be built outside of Japan) and was among the most heavily armed ships in any Navy. She received two major reconstructions throughout her life, the first being in 1929, she was rebuilt as a battleship, then later in 1935, along with her sister vessels, her superstructure was completely rebuilt, resulting in an increased rate of knots that would allow her to keep pace with the developing carrier groups – thus reclassifying her a s a fast-battleship.

KongÅ’s World War II service history includes covering the Japanese amphibious landings in British Malaya and the Dutch East Indies in 1942, shortly before engaging American forces and Midway and during the Guadalcanal campaign. 1943 saw her almost entirely stationed in the Caroline Islands, only being deployed in response to aircraft carrier raids against Japanese Islands scattered across the Pacific. She was part of the Battles of the Philippine Sea and Leyte Gulf in 1944, successfully sinking enemy vessels in the latter. Her ultimate fate was at the hands of a US Submarine (USS Sealion) whilst crossing the Formosa Strait on 21 November 1944. She has the unfortunate distinction of being the sole Japanese battleship sunk by submarine in WW2.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: Zuikaku
Description:
Zuikaku ( ç‘žé¶´ “Auspicious Crane”), a ShÅkaku-class aircraft carrier, along with her sister ship, were the most successful carriers operated by the Japanese Navy during WW2. The Japanese had learnt many lessons prior to her construction and as such Zuikaku was considerably larger, better armed, and had a higher aircraft capacity than previous purpose-built Japanese Carriers. Setting sail in November 1941, her complement of aircraft included 18 Mitsubushi A6M fighters, 27 Aichi D3A dive bombers and 27 Nakajima B5n torpedo bombers.

She was part of the task force whose aircraft attacked Pearl Harbor in December 1941, and was a prominent participant in many subsequent battles in the Pacific Ocean – including, Java, Ceylon, the Coral Sea, the Eastern Solomons, Santa Cruz, the Philippine Seas and Leyte Gulf. It was at this last action that she was sunk, at the Battle of Cape Engano on 25 October 1944. She was the last of the six carriers that participated in the Pearl Harbor attack to be sunk.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: Suzuya
Description:
The heavy cruiser, Suzuya, is believed to be one of the deepest shipwrecks on record at (a yet) unconfirmed 27,600 feet. She met her fate at the Battle of Leyte Gulf when she was beset upon by carrier-based aircraft – a torpedo exploding in her own tubes set off a chain reaction of fired and damage that forced the ship’s abandonment.

Prior to her sinking, she was involved in covering the landings at Malaya, the invasion of Sarawak, raids in the Indian Ocean, The Midway invasion force, the Solomon Islands, and the Battle of the Philippine Sea.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: Mikuma
Description:
The second of the four Mogami class heavy cruisers, Mikuma was completed in 1935 but quickly underwent refits to replace her main turrets with twin 203 mm guns. Her former weapons, triple 155mm guns went to Yamato. Early in her career she was tasked with the occupation of Cochinchina, the invasion of Malaya and the invasion of British Borneo.

At the Battle of Sundra Strait Mikuma engaged the Allied cruisers USS Houston and HMS Perth, both of which were sunk. Mikuma then participated in the Indian Ocean Raids, before being recalled for the Midway operation. It was here she met her demise; on 5 June 1944, she was badly damaged by a friendly ship collision attempting to evade US submarine torpedo attacks. A succession of attempted airborne attacks, from B-17s to Vought SB2U Vindicators all failed. The next morning, however, SBD Dauntless dive bombers from USS Enterprise and Hornet managed to successfully inflict 5 bomb hits resulting in a cataclysmic chain reaction of explosions of the onboard AA shells and torpedoes.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: Yahagi
Description:
'Yahagi was the third of the Agano class of light cruiser, intended to be the flagship of a destroyer flotilla. She was completed in December 1943. She participated in the Battles of the Philippine and Leyte Gulf and remained relatively unscathed despite weathering repeated attacks by enemy aircraft during these actions.

She was one of the vessels instructed to accompany Yamato on its final suicide run against the American invaders off Okinawa. On 7 April 1945, this task force was beset by 386 enemy aircraft. During the first wave of these attacks, Yahagi was struck directly in the engine room, and rendered unmovable. Subsequent waves rained more bombs and torpedoes upon her, such damage making rescue impossible.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: Kagero-class Destroyers
Description:
Essentially an enlarged Fubuki-class, the KagerÅ-class hull design was scaled up to overcome earlier design deficiencies. As a result, the KagerÅ-class was the equal of any of its contemporaries in other navies and superior to most. Only the initial lack of radar and continued poor quality of sonar equipment and anti-aircraft defences (shortcomings which bedevilled all Japanese destroyers) hindered their performance.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: USS New Mexico
Description:
USS New Mexico (BB-40) was the lead of her class of battleship and served with the United States Navy between 1918 and 1946. She was the first ship with a turbo-electric transmission, capable of a cruising speed of 10 knots. She served as an escort to President Woodrow Wilson’s voyage to Brest, France, for the signing of the Treaty of Versailles. She operated repeated exercises in Pacific and Atlantic waters in the interwar period and received major modernisation between 1931 and 1933.

Initially, in World War II, the vessel was involved in neutrality operations in the Atlantic. This soon changed after the attack on Pearl Harbor. She returned to the Atlantic and participated in shore bombardments including at Attu and Kiska, Tarawa, the Marshall Islands, the Mariana and Palau Islands Leyte, Luzon and Okinawa. She also performed escort duties, patrols and received refits during this period. USS New Mexico was subject to repeated kamikaze attacks during her WW2 service, which inflicted heavy damage and loss of life. However, she persevered and was present in Tokyo Bay for the Japanese surrender that officially ended the war.

—description from the publisher

Name: Victory at Sea: USS Essex
Description:
Built during World War Two, USS Essex was the lead of her class of aircraft carriers. She was commissioned in December 1942 and went on to serve in several campaigns in the Pacific Theatre of operations. For her efforts, she received the Presidential Unit Citation and 13 battle stars. She operated right until the finale of the war, participating in the final raids against the Japanese home islands between 10 July to 15 August 1945.

Though already moderately armed, the primary offensive capability of a carrier was, of course, its aircraft, known as “Sunday Punch”. This comprised up to 36 fighters, 36 dive bombers and 18 torpedo bombers. Typically, the standard fighter would be the Grumman F6F Hellcat, the dive-bomber/scout the Curtiss SB2C Helldiver and the torpedo bomber the Grumman TBF Avenger as the torpedo bomber.

At the close of the war, Essex was decommissioned but modernized and recommissioned in the 1950s, serving as an anti-Submarine carrier. During this time, she participated in the Korean War and was key in the Cuban Missile Crisis. She also has the distinction of being the primary recovery carrier for the Apollo 7 space mission.

—description from the publisher

Name: Tanzimat: Reform & Crisis in the Ottoman Empire
Description:
This historical semi-cooperative Eurogame is set in the Ottoman Empire between 1839 and 1876, at the time of the Tanzimat reforms. The Tanzimat reforms were an ambitious attempt on the part of liberally minded Ottoman sultans and politicians to modernize the aging empire and thereby keep it from disintegrating.

Players in the game represent Ottoman court factions who enlist Statesmen to use their bonuses, enact Reforms and reduce the number of Troubles in the empire. They must keep an eye on three common resources: Finances, Army and Standing. Event cards are drawn at the start of each turn that add new Troubles to the map, possibly causing Revolts.

The game consists of two Ages. At the end of each Age, a Crisis happens. (The Crisis may happen earlier if the number of Troubles and Revolts reach a critical number.) Only one player can win, but all players can lose if they let the empire crumble.

—description from the designer
The game is fully PnP!

COMPONENT LIST
 1 rulebook
 1 game board
 40 Statesmen cards
 30 Event cards
 30 Reform cards
 24 Sultan’s Decree cards
 16 Legacy cards
 9x4 buildings (Schools, Factories, Juries)
 24 markers (partitions, Finances, Army, Standing, income, Loans, Revolts, game effects)
 40 cubes (Troubles) - not included in the game!
 5x4 cylinders (Influence, player order, VP, offices, Reform stage) - not included in the game!

Name: Great Minds
Description:
Great Minds is an easy party game where players must solve the puzzle to escape the mind maze.

The mind maze grid board is laid out with 25 clue cards. Each of the clue cards is a different word. Players then take a set of mind cards numbered 1 to 5 and a 2 matching coloured mind tokens, these tokens represent them in the game. The mind maze board also contains a score tracker, and one of the player tokens is added to this tracker.

At the beginning of the game, there will be 25 cards on the mind maze board with different words. Each card has a grid reference letter and number attached to it. The center card of the mind maze grid (C3) is removed and becomes the first clue.

Starting with the top row, player secretly select and play, face down, a numbered mind card relating to a word on the grip and the initial clue. Once all players have played a card, the card are all turned over and players place their mind token on their chosen word. Players get a point if they have successfully picked the same word as another player. The word(or words) with the most votes, becomes the clue for the next row. Once a row is complete, the words on that row are flipped over to reveal new words. Play continues down the mind grid, once player reach the bottom, they go back to the top of the grid, but now the words are different and there are less of them.

When all words have been eliminated from the mind maze, the player with the highest score wins.

—description from the designer

Name: Onetop Football
Description:
ONETOP FOOTBALL is a football card game that anyone can easily enjoy with real football rules.

How to play
â‘  They are divided into home team and away team.
â‘¡ Out of 10 tactical cards, choose 5 cards to use as your tactics, mix them well with 23 player cards, and place them as shown in the picture. (Set aside tactical cards that are not used.)
â‘¢ Each player draws 5 cards from the top of the deck and holds them invisible to the other party.

Game progress
â‘  Each player turns one player card over and places them in the midfield area.
â‘¡ In the midfield area, the number of passes of player cards is compared.
â‘¢ The winning player compares the player cards in the opponent's penalty area when comparing the next player cards.
â‘£ In the penalty area, place 1 player card face down invisibly.
â‘¤ Compare the attack number of the attacking player card with the defending number of the defending player.
â‘¥ If you win by comparing player cards in the opponent's penalty area, you will score 1 point.
â‘¦ If you lose in the penalty area, return to the midfield area and compare the player cards.
â‘§ If the number of player cards to be compared is the same, compare again with other player cards on the spot.
â‘¨ The used cards are stacked in the used card deck, and the number of cards used in the new card deck is taken from the top, and the play continues while maintaining 5 cards.
â‘© Place the scored player card in front of you to make it easier to calculate the score after the game.
â‘ª Only one tactical card can be used.
(Tactical cards that are used with player cards are turned over so that the opponent cannot see them and placed next to the compared player cards.)
â‘« If one of the players has no more player cards to compare, the match ends. The player with the highest total score is the winner.
â‘¬ If the score is the same, each player selects 5 player cards randomly and compares the attack numbers one by one. The player with the highest number of cards won is the final winner.

Name: Dark Rituals: Malleus Maleficarum – The Banshee
Description:
Banshee (from Village Attacks, in collaboration with Grimlord Games) adds a reimagined Banshee, a Wind Witch to the game!

This mini-expansion to Dark Rituals: Malleus Maleficarum comes with a Banshee Witch miniature, Witch ID card, Grimoire, 3 Witchcraft Spells, and bonus Creature ID Cards and Summoning cards for Leshy, Wendigo and the Succubus from Village Attacks.

Name: Dark Rituals: Malleus Maleficarum – Horvath and Dagon
Description:
Horvath and Dagon (from Black Rose Wars, in collaboration with Ludus Magnus Studio) adds a male Witch to the game!  Bound to his familiar Dagon, Horvath drains the Creature's health to keep himself alive.

This mini-expansion to Dark Rituals: Malleus Maleficarum comes with a Horvath and Dagon miniature, Horvath and Dagon Witch ID card, Grimoire, 3 Witchcraft Spells, and a bonus separate Dagon Creature ID card and Summoning card.

Name: LISTicles
Description: A category card and a bonus letter are revealed each round. Players have 90 seconds to write out seven entries that fulfill the category. Only unique answers will score and entries that begin with the bonus letter earn extra points. Play continues until 4 rounds are played. Each player adds up their scores for all four rounds and the player with the most points wins the game.

Name: Operation Market Garden
Description:
World War 2 in your pocket Operation Market Garden  is a two player card game, ideal as a filler before or after your main gaming event. Also great as a travel game to take on holiday or when you're out with friends. It plays in 20-40 minutes for players aged 8+.  It's quick to learn but strategic, learn from your enemy and try to get inside their mind to work out what sequence they will lay their cards down.  Artwork by Adrian Stone.

Recreating the largest airborne invasion in history, Operation Market Garden in World War 2.  Use your battle and tactic cards to out smart your opponent, use your equipment wisely, reveal events and monitor your divisions. Can you win enough battles to secure the vital bridges, will you be able to capture and hold all of them in time?

Each round consists of 7 battles, to win a battle the player must have the highest points score. The player will combine, battle, tactic, equipment and event cards to get to their total score.  Whoever wins the most battles wins the bridge.  The Allied player must win the bridge to proceed to the next bridge a draw is not enough.  Players will take it in turns to be the Allied player to see how many bridges they can capture.  The German player can reduce the effectiveness of the Allied player by altering the Allied Division cards, the Allied player can try and counter this using the Victoria Cross card but these are limited so you must use them wisely.

Events can be positive or negative for both sides.  Players must try and work out what sequence their opponent will lay down their cards.  They must remember what cards have already been used and try and get inside their opponents mind to out think them, what did they do last round, will they do the same thing, which combinations of cards do they favour, when should I use my Victoria Cross card.  There are only 3 equipment and 3 tactic cards for each side so they must be used carefully.  Can you get your opponent to use their most powerful card on your weakest card?

-description from designer

Name: Liege 1914
Description:
The Battle of Liege was the opening engagement of the First World War and the first step of the German Schlieffen Plan. Liege, a city protected by a ring of twelve forts, blocked the passage of the German First and Second Armies. It contained the railway bridges crossing the Meuse river that would be needed by the advancing armies. Winning a quick victory over the Belgians was critical to the success of the German plan so a surprise attack of six brigades was launched ahead of the heavy artillery that ultimately destroyed the forts.

Liege 1914 is a regimental-level simulation of this opening battle of the Great War. Players assume the roles of the commanders of the German and Belgian troops as they desperately fight for this valuable position in the line.

The 17 x 22" map shows the western portion of Belgium from the German border to Liege. The 240 1/2" counters (die-cut and back-printed) show German and Belgian forces involved in the battle.

Liege 1914 is now the second installment in the Great War Battles series. Based on the Ypres 1914 game system (the first in the series), the Great War Battles is a series of games devoted to simulating battles of the First World War. Battles are covered at the brigade/regiment level using a common set of rules. Games in the series will cover a variety of situations ranging from trench warfare to open fighting.

Name: Het Deventer Spel
Description: You will make an exciting and informative stroll, by rolling dice to move, through Deventer where you ultimately have to collect three eagles. By answering questions, collecting properties and some luck you can earn enough money to buy the three eagles. Which player will win the game after several strolls through Deventer and deliver the three eagles at the missionary of the Lebuïnus Church?

Name: Gundalow
Description:
Get ready to set sail!

Set in the Seacoast region around Portsmouth, New Hampshire, you will travel the waterways as the captain of your own gundalow - a flat-bottomed sailboat historically used for transporting cargo. Each player starts the game in one of six towns around Great Bay. Each town will have its own unique market of available and wanted goods, drawn from a deck of market cards. Players use their money to purchase goods from the markets for delivery to other towns in order to make a profit. Players can also pick up passengers who are looking for transport to other towns.

After loading the goods and passengers onto their gundalow, players roll a die to sail to other towns around Great Bay and the Piscataqua River. The deepwater port of Portsmouth has exotic and highly-profitable goods available (such as spices and cotton) but it’s a long journey down the Piscataqua River.

Event cards come into play when players land on the event squares on the game board. Event cards offer new challenges and opportunities to players and will create dynamic and exciting market conditions. Players may need to adjust their trade routes to be successful! Resourcefulness and flexibility are the keys to successfully competing against the other gundalow captains.

The game ends when one player accumulates $100. Players then tally their goods and passengers delivered, and the players with the highest totals receive one or more of several honorary titles and victory cards. Will you earn the coveted “Richest Captain” honorary title (awarded to the player who accumulates the most money) or perhaps the gratifying “Friend to Farmers” honorary title (awarded to the player who delivers the most marsh hay). With a rich variety of goods, markets, and events, each game of Gundalow is unique, challenging, and rewarding. The game also comes with several suggested variants, which all combine to create a fun game with limitless variability.

-description from designer
